div.p: In this note we prove the Weinstein conjecture for a class of symplectic manifolds including the uniruled manifolds based on Liu-Tian’s result.

p.span: The Weinstein conjecture in the uniruled manifolds
Guangcun Lu111Partially supported by the NNSF 19971045 of China.

div.p: [5pt] Nankai Institute of Mathematics, Nankai University
Tianjin 300071, P. R. China
[5pt] (E-mail: gclu@nankai.edu.cn)
[3pt]
Key words : Weinstein conjecture, Gromov-Witten invariants, uniruled manifold.

Since 1978 A. Weinstein proposed his famous conjecture that every hypersurface of contact type in the symplectic manifolds carries a closed characteristic([We]), many results were obtained (cf.[C][FHV][H][HV1][HV2][LiuT][Lu1][Lu2][V1][V2][V3]) after C.Viterbo first proved it in (ℝ2⁢n,ω0)superscriptℝ2𝑛subscript𝜔0OPEN:( ATOM:symbol-ℝ POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(\mbox{\Bb R}^{2n},\omega_{0}) in 1986([V1]). Not long ago Gang Liu and Gang Tian established a deep relation between this conjecture and the Gromov-Witten invariants and got several general results as corollaries([LiuT]).

Assume S𝑆italic-SS to be a hypersurface of contact type in a closed connected symplectic manifold (V,ω)𝑉𝜔OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:)(V,\omega) separating V𝑉italic-VV in the sense of [LiuT], i.e. there exist submanifolds V+subscript𝑉italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{+} and V-subscript𝑉italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{-} with common boundary S𝑆italic-SS such that V=V+∪V-𝑉subscript𝑉subscript𝑉italic-V RELOP:equals italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:union italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV=V_{+}\cup V_{-} and S=V+∩V-𝑆subscript𝑉subscript𝑉italic-S RELOP:equals italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:intersection italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS=V_{+}\cap V_{-}, then the following result holds.

Theorem 1([LiuT]) If there exist A∈H2⁢(V;ℤ)𝐴subscript𝐻2𝑉ℤitalic-A RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℤ CLOSE:)A\in H_{2}(V;\mbox{\Bb Z}) and α+,α-∈H∗⁢(V;ℚ)subscript𝛼subscript𝛼subscript𝐻normal-∗𝑉ℚitalic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℚ CLOSE:)\alpha_{+},\,\alpha_{-}\in H_{\ast}(V;\mbox{\Bb Q}), such that

italic-s italic-u italic-p italic-p OPEN:( italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARROW:hookrightarrow italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C PUNCT:; italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℚ CLOSE:)

italic-C RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℚ CLOSE:)

p.span: then S𝑆italic-SS carries at least one closed characteristic.

div.p: Recall that for a given A∈H2⁢(V;ℤ)𝐴subscript𝐻2𝑉ℤitalic-A RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℤ CLOSE:)A\in H_{2}(V;\mbox{\Bb Z}) the Gromov-Witten invariant of genus g𝑔italic-gg and with m+2 marked points is a homomorphism

semantics.annotation: Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end METARELOP:colon italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℚ CLOSE:) MULOP:times italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℚ CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to ATOM:symbol-ℚ PUNCT:,

div.p: (see [FO][LiT][R][Si]). Though one so far does not yet know whether the GW invariants defined in the four papers agree or not, we believe that they have the same vanishing or nonvanishing properties, i.e., for any given classes C∈H∗⁢(ℳ¯g,m+2;ℚ)𝐶subscript𝐻∗subscript¯ℳ𝑔𝑚2ℚitalic-C RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℚ CLOSE:)C\in H_{\ast}(\overline{\cal M}_{g,m+2};\mbox{\Bb Q}) and β1,⋯,βm+2∈H∗⁢(V;ℚ)subscript𝛽1⋯subscript𝛽𝑚2subscript𝐻∗𝑉ℚitalic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℚ CLOSE:)\beta_{1},\cdots,\beta_{m+2}\in H_{\ast}(V;\mbox{\Bb Q}) one of this four versions vanishes on (C;β1,⋯,βm+2)𝐶subscript𝛽1⋯subscript𝛽𝑚2OPEN:( italic-C PUNCT:; italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(C;\beta_{1},\cdots,\beta_{m+2}) if and only if any other three ones vanish on them. In addition, the version of [R] is actually a homomorphism from H∗⁢(ℳ¯g,m+2;ℝ)×H∗⁢(V;ℝ)m+2subscript𝐻∗subscript¯ℳ𝑔𝑚2ℝsubscript𝐻∗superscript𝑉ℝ𝑚2italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℝ CLOSE:) MULOP:times italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℝ CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endH_{\ast}(\overline{\cal M}_{g,m+2};\mbox{\Bb R})\times H_{\ast}(V;\mbox{\Bb R}% )^{m+2} to ℝ. However, using the facts that H∗⁢(M;ℚ)subscript𝐻∗𝑀ℚitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℚ CLOSE:)H_{\ast}(M;\mbox{\Bb Q}) is dense H∗⁢(M;ℝ)subscript𝐻∗𝑀ℝitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℝ CLOSE:)H_{\ast}(M;\mbox{\Bb R}) for M=V,ℳ¯g,k𝑀𝑉subscript¯ℳ𝑔𝑘italic-M RELOP:equals italic-V PUNCT:, OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM=V,\overline{\cal M}_{g,k} and ΨA,g,m+2subscriptΨ𝐴𝑔𝑚2Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Psi_{A,g,m+2} is always a homomorphism one can naturally extend the other three versions to the homomorphisms from H∗⁢(ℳ¯g,m+2;ℝ)×H∗⁢(V;ℝ)m+2subscript𝐻∗subscript¯ℳ𝑔𝑚2ℝsubscript𝐻∗superscript𝑉ℝ𝑚2italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℝ CLOSE:) MULOP:times italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℝ CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endH_{\ast}(\overline{\cal M}_{g,m+2};\mbox{\Bb R})\times H_{\ast}(V;\mbox{\Bb R}% )^{m+2} to ℝ. Below we always mean the extended versions when they can not clearly explained in the original versions. Our main result is

p.span: For a connected closed symplectic manifold (V,ω)𝑉𝜔OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:)(V,\omega), if there exist A∈H2⁢(V;ℤ)𝐴subscript𝐻2𝑉ℤitalic-A RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℤ CLOSE:)A\in H_{2}(V;\mbox{\Bb Z}), C∈H∗⁢(M¯g,m+2;ℚ)𝐶subscript𝐻normal-∗subscriptnormal-¯normal-M𝑔𝑚2ℚitalic-C RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℚ CLOSE:)C\in H_{\ast}(\overline{\cal M}_{g,m+2};\mbox{\Bb Q}) and β1,⋯,βm+1∈H∗⁢(V;ℚ)subscript𝛽1normal-⋯subscript𝛽𝑚1subscript𝐻normal-∗𝑉ℚitalic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℚ CLOSE:)\beta_{1},\cdots,\beta_{m+1}\in H_{\ast}(V;\mbox{\Bb Q}) such that

semantics.annotation: Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0

p.span: for (g,m)≠(0,0)𝑔𝑚00OPEN:( italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals OPEN:( NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)(g,m)\neq(0,0) and the single point class [p⁢t]delimited-[]𝑝𝑡OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:][pt], then every hypersurface of contact type S𝑆italic-SS in the symplectic manifold V𝑉italic-VV separating V𝑉italic-VV carries a closed characteristic. Specially, if g=0𝑔0italic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:0g=0 we can also guarantee that S𝑆italic-SS carries one contractible ( in V𝑉italic-VV) closed characteristic.

div.p: In case g=0𝑔0italic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:0g=0 it is not difficult to prove that Proposition 2.5(5) and Proposition 2.6 in [RT] still hold for any closed symplectic manifold (V,ω)𝑉𝜔OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:)(V,\omega) with the method of [R]. That is,

Ψ0,0,k⁢([p⁢t];α1,⋯,αk)=α1∩⋯∩αksubscriptΨ00𝑘delimited-[]𝑝𝑡subscript𝛼1⋯subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝛼1⋯subscript𝛼𝑘Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:; italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:intersection ID:cdots ADDOP:intersection italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Psi_{0,0,k}([pt];\alpha_{1},\cdots,\alpha_{k})=\alpha_{1}\cap\cdots\cap\alpha% _{k}( the intersection number);

for the product manifold (V,ω)=(V1×V2,ω1⊕ω2)𝑉𝜔subscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2direct-sumsubscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:direct-sum italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(V,\omega)=(V_{1}\times V_{2},\omega_{1}\oplus\omega_{2}) of any two closed symplectic manifolds (V1,ω1)subscript𝑉1subscript𝜔1OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(V_{1},\omega_{1}) and (V2,ω2)subscript𝑉2subscript𝜔2OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(V_{2},\omega_{2}) it holds that

div.p: Thus if ΨA2,0,m+1V2⁢([p⁢t];[p⁢t],β1,⋯,βm)≠0subscriptsuperscriptΨsubscript𝑉2subscript𝐴20𝑚1delimited-[]𝑝𝑡delimited-[]𝑝𝑡subscript𝛽1⋯subscript𝛽𝑚0Psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0\Psi^{V_{2}}_{A_{2},0,m+1}([pt];[pt],\beta_{1},\cdots,\beta_{m})\neq 0 we get

semantics.annotation: Psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0

div.p: for A1=0subscript𝐴10italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0A_{1}=0 and α1=⋯=αm=[V1]subscript𝛼1⋯subscript𝛼𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝑉1italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ID:cdots RELOP:equals italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:[ italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]\alpha_{1}=\cdots=\alpha_{m}=[V_{1}]. This leads to

p.span: Weinstein conjecture holds in the product symplectic manifolds of any closed symplectic manifold and a symplectic manifold satisfying the condition of Theorem 2 for g=0𝑔0italic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:0g=0.

div.p: Recall that a smooth Kahler manifold (M,ω)𝑀𝜔OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:)(M,\omega) is called uniruled if it can be covered by rational curves. Y. Miyaoka and S. Mori showed that a smooth complex projective manifold X𝑋italic-XX is uniruled if and only if there exists a non-empty open subset U⊂X𝑈𝑋italic-U RELOP:subset-of italic-XU\subset X such that for every x∈U𝑥𝑈italic-x RELOP:element-of italic-Ux\in U there is an irreducible curve C𝐶italic-CC with (KX,C)<0subscript𝐾𝑋𝐶0OPEN:( italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-C CLOSE:) RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0(K_{X},C)<0 through x𝑥italic-xx([MiMo]). Specially, any Fano manifold is uniruled([Ko]). The complex projective spaces, the complete intersections in it, the Grassmann manifolds and more general flag manifold are the important examples of the Fano manifolds. In [R, Prop. 4.9] it was proved that if a smooth Kahler manifold M𝑀italic-MM is symplectic deformation equivalient to uniruled manifold, M𝑀italic-MM is uniruled. Actually, as mentioned there, Kollar showed that on the uniruled manifold (M,ω)𝑀𝜔OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:)(M,\omega) there exists a class A∈H2⁢(V;ℤ)𝐴subscript𝐻2𝑉ℤitalic-A RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℤ CLOSE:)A\in H_{2}(V;\mbox{\Bb Z}) such that

semantics.annotation: Phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0

div.p: for some classes β1subscript𝛽1italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\beta_{1} and β2subscript𝛽2italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\beta_{2}(see [R] for more general case). Combing these with Corollary 3 we get

p.span: Every hypersurface S𝑆italic-SS of contact type in the uniruled manifold V𝑉italic-VV or the product of any closed symplectic manifold and an uniruled manifold carries one contractible ( in V𝑉italic-VV) closed characteristic.

div.p: The ideas of proof are combing Liu-Tian’s Theorem 1 above, the properties of the Gromov-Witten invariants and Viterbro’s trick of [V4].
Proof of Theorem 2 Under the assumptions of Theorem 2, the reduction formula of the Gromov-Witten invariants([R, Prop. C]) implies that

semantics.annotation: Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-P italic-D OPEN:( OPEN:[ italic-omega CLOSE:] CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-omega OPEN:( italic-A CLOSE:) MULOP:cdot Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0

div.p: since A𝐴italic-AA contains the nontrivial pseudoholomorphic curves. To use Theorem 1 we need to show that there exists a homology class γ∈H2⁢(V;ℝ)𝛾subscript𝐻2𝑉ℝitalic-gamma RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-ℝ CLOSE:)\gamma\in H_{2}(V;\mbox{\Bb R}) with support s⁢u⁢p⁢p⁢(γ)↪i⁢n⁢t⁢(V+)↪𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝𝛾𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝑉italic-s italic-u italic-p italic-p OPEN:( italic-gamma CLOSE:) ARROW:hookrightarrow italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)supp(\gamma)\hookrightarrow int(V_{+})( or i⁢n⁢t⁢(V-)𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝑉italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)int(V_{-})) such that

semantics.annotation: Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-gamma PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0 PERIOD:.

div.p: To this goal we note S𝑆italic-SS to be a hypersurface of contact type, and thus there exists a Liouville vector field X𝑋italic-XX defined in a neighborhood U𝑈italic-UU of S𝑆italic-SS, which is transverse to S𝑆italic-SS. The flow of X𝑋italic-XX define a diffeomorphism ΦΦPhi\Phi from S×(-3⁢ϵ,3⁢ϵ)𝑆3italic-ϵ3italic-ϵitalic-S MULOP:times OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 italic-epsilon PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 italic-epsilon CLOSE:)S\times(-3\epsilon,3\epsilon) onto an open neighborhood of S𝑆italic-SS in U𝑈italic-UU for some ϵ>0italic-ϵ0italic-epsilon RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0\epsilon>0. Here we may assume Φ⁢(S×(-3⁢ϵ,0])⊂V+Φ𝑆3italic-ϵ0subscript𝑉Phi OPEN:( italic-S MULOP:times OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 italic-epsilon PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:] CLOSE:) RELOP:subset-of italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Phi(S\times(-3\epsilon,0])\subset V_{+} and Φ⁢(S×[0,3⁢ϵ))⊂V-Φ𝑆03italic-ϵsubscript𝑉Phi OPEN:( italic-S MULOP:times OPEN:[ NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 italic-epsilon CLOSE:) CLOSE:) RELOP:subset-of italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Phi(S\times[0,3\epsilon))\subset V_{-}. For any 0<δ<3⁢ϵ0𝛿3italic-ϵNUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than italic-delta RELOP:less-than NUMBER:3 italic-epsilon0<\delta<3\epsilon let us denote by Uδ:=Φ⁢(S×[-δ,δ])assignsubscript𝑈𝛿Φ𝑆𝛿𝛿italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:assign Phi OPEN:( italic-S MULOP:times OPEN:[ ADDOP:minus italic-delta PUNCT:, italic-delta CLOSE:] CLOSE:)U_{\delta}:=\Phi(S\times[-\delta,\delta]). We also denote by α=iX⁢ω𝛼subscript𝑖𝑋𝜔italic-alpha RELOP:equals italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-omega\alpha=i_{X}\omega, then d⁢α=ω𝑑𝛼𝜔italic-d italic-alpha RELOP:equals italic-omegad\alpha=\omega on U𝑈italic-UU. Choose a smooth function f:V→ℝ:𝑓→𝑉ℝitalic-f METARELOP:colon italic-V ARROW:to ATOM:symbol-ℝf:V\to\mbox{\Bb R} such that f|Uϵ≡1evaluated-at𝑓subscript𝑈italic-ϵ1italic-f VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:1f|_{U_{\epsilon}}\equiv 1 and vanishes outside U2⁢ϵsubscript𝑈2italic-ϵitalic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{2\epsilon}. Define β:=f⁢αassign𝛽𝑓𝛼italic-beta RELOP:assign italic-f italic-alpha\beta:=f\alpha. This is a smooth 11NUMBER:11-form on V𝑉italic-VV, and d⁢β=ω𝑑𝛽𝜔italic-d italic-beta RELOP:equals italic-omegad\beta=\omega on Uϵsubscript𝑈italic-ϵitalic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{\epsilon}. Denote by ω^=ω-d⁢β^𝜔𝜔𝑑𝛽OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-omega ARG:end RELOP:equals italic-omega ADDOP:minus italic-d italic-beta\widehat{\omega}=\omega-d\beta. Then ω^|Uϵ≡0evaluated-at^𝜔subscript𝑈italic-ϵ0OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-omega ARG:end VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:0\widehat{\omega}|_{U_{\epsilon}}\equiv 0 and thus cohomology classes [ω]=[ω^]delimited-[]𝜔delimited-[]^𝜔OPEN:[ italic-omega CLOSE:] RELOP:equals OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-omega ARG:end CLOSE:][\omega]=[\widehat{\omega}] is in H2⁢(V,Uϵ)superscript𝐻2𝑉subscript𝑈italic-ϵitalic-H POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)H^{2}(V,U_{\epsilon}). Now from the naturality of Poincare-Lefschetz duality ([p.296, Sp]): H2⁢n-2⁢(V-Uϵ)≅H2⁢(V,Uϵ)subscript𝐻2𝑛2𝑉subscript𝑈italic-ϵsuperscript𝐻2𝑉subscript𝑈italic-ϵitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals italic-H POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)H_{2n-2}(V-U_{\epsilon})\cong H^{2}(V,U_{\epsilon}) it follows that we can choose a cycle representive γ^^𝛾OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end\widehat{\gamma} of γ:=P⁢D⁢([ω])assign𝛾𝑃𝐷delimited-[]𝜔italic-gamma RELOP:assign italic-P italic-D OPEN:( OPEN:[ italic-omega CLOSE:] CLOSE:)\gamma:=PD([\omega]) with support s⁢u⁢p⁢p⁢(γ^)↪i⁢n⁢t⁢(V-Uϵ)↪𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝^𝛾𝑖𝑛𝑡𝑉subscript𝑈italic-ϵitalic-s italic-u italic-p italic-p OPEN:( OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end CLOSE:) ARROW:hookrightarrow italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)supp(\widehat{\gamma})\hookrightarrow int(V-U_{\epsilon}). Notice that V-Uϵ⊂V-S=i⁢n⁢t⁢(V+)∪i⁢n⁢t⁢(V-)𝑉subscript𝑈italic-ϵ𝑉𝑆𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝑉𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝑉italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:subset-of italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-S RELOP:equals italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:union italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)V-U_{\epsilon}\subset V-S=int(V_{+})\cup int(V_{-}) and i⁢n⁢t⁢(V+)∩i⁢n⁢t⁢(V-)=∅𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝑉𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝑉italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:intersection italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ID:empty-setint(V_{+})\cap int(V_{-})=\emptyset. We can denote by γ^+subscript^𝛾OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\widehat{\gamma}_{+} and γ^-subscript^𝛾OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\widehat{\gamma}_{-} the union of connected components of γ^^𝛾OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end\widehat{\gamma} lying i⁢n⁢t⁢(V+)𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝑉italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)int(V_{+}) and i⁢n⁢t⁢(V-)𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝑉italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)int(V_{-}) respectively. Then the homology classes determined by them in H∗⁢(V,ℝ)subscript𝐻∗𝑉ℝitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, ATOM:symbol-ℝ CLOSE:)H_{\ast}(V,\mbox{\Bb R}) satisfy: [γ^+]+[γ^-]=γdelimited-[]subscript^𝛾delimited-[]subscript^𝛾𝛾OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] ADDOP:plus OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] RELOP:equals italic-gamma[\widehat{\gamma}_{+}]+[\widehat{\gamma}_{-}]=\gamma. Thus [γ^+]delimited-[]subscript^𝛾OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:][\widehat{\gamma}_{+}] and [γ^-]delimited-[]subscript^𝛾OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:][\widehat{\gamma}_{-}] have at least one nonzero class. By the property of the Gromov-Witten invariants we get

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-gamma PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0 PERIOD:.

div.p: Hence the right side of (4) has at least one nonzero term. Without loss of generality we assume that

semantics.annotation: Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0 PERIOD:.

div.p: Then Theorem 1 directly leads to the first conclusion.
The second claim is easily obtained by carefully checking the arguments in [LiuT]. □□Box\Box

Remark 5 Actually we believe that Theorem 1 still holds provided the hypersurface S𝑆italic-SS of contact type therein is replaced by the stable hypersurface in the sense of [HV2]. Hence the hypersurface S𝑆italic-SS of contact type in our results above may be replaced by the stable hypersurface for which the symplectic form is exact in some open neighborhood of it.

Remark 6 In [B] it was proved that the system of Gromov-Witten invariants of the product of two varieties is equal to the tensor product of the systems of Gromov-Witten invariants of the two factors. Using the methods developed in [FO][LiT][R][Si] we believe that one can still prove these product formula of Gromov-Witten invariants with any genus for any product of two closed symplectic manifolds, and thus Corollary 3 also holds for any genus g𝑔italic-gg.

Acknowledgements I would like to express my hearty thanks to Professor Claude Viterbo for his many valuable discussions and sending his recent preprint [V4] to me. I wish to acknowledge Professor Janos Kollar for his telling me some properties on the uniruled manifolds. He also thanks the referee for his good suggestions to improve the original version.

C. Viterbo, A proof of the Weinstein conjecture in ℝ2⁢nsuperscriptℝ2𝑛ATOM:symbol-ℝ POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mbox{\Bb R}^{2n}, Ann. Inst. H. Poincaré Analyses Nonlinéaire, 4 (1987), 337–356.
